key_points: Citigroup unsuccessfully attempted to recover over $500 million it accidentally wired to Revlon lenders.
U.S. District Judge Jesse Furman ruled against Citigroup, allowing recipients to keep the funds because they discharged valid debts and weren't aware of Citigroup's mistake.
The decision was based on a specific exception in New York law concerning mistaken wire transfers.
The overpayment was intended to be a much smaller interest payment of approximately $7.8 million instead of the $893 million actually sent.
Some lenders had returned part of the overpayment, but the incident led to numerous lawsuits.
Citigroup has stated it "strongly disagrees" with the court's decision and plans to appeal.
Shares of Citigroup were up 0.7% following the news of the court ruling.
The wire transfer mistake in August heightened regulatory scrutiny over Citigroup's internal practices.
In October, Citigroup was fined $400 million for risk management, data governance, and internal controls deficiencies.
The ruling includes the judge's statement indicating the unlikelihood and unprecedented nature of such a massive banking error.
